div1.p: Department of State Monrovia February 2, 1882
Sir I am directed by the President after careful and anxious deliberation in the Cabinet to request you lay before your govern- ment the following:

The Republic of Liberia whose origin and history are well known to the govenrment of the United States has now reached a period in her history when she surely needs and is fully able to bear a large influx of civilized descendants of Africa from the United States. An important addition to her civilized population is imperatively demanded if she is to go extending her influence and pushing her free insitutions against the encroachment of foreigners.

The natives in the interior of the Republic are anxious for the planting of civilized settlements on the beautiful hills and in the futile valleys which diversify their interesting country. We are pushing on as fact as we can get the emmigrants from the United States and our new settlements of civilized industry as they advance.
Arthington and Bremerville foundecd about two years ago in dense forests by freed men from North Carolina, Mississipi, Alabama

Lousiana and Arkansas are now beautiful coffee groves with their computable fame buildings Christian Churches, School houses and workshops, and as the Represetatives of teh Christian religion and of American life are attracting the Aborigines drawing them both within and around the settlments. But in view of the most work to be done, it is comparatively little that can be prosecuted or accom plished by the few emigrants sent out at irregular intervals by a private association depending for its means upon voluntary contri- butions.

The Shebro and Sierra Leone rivers within British jurisdiction and having no settlements of civilized people are frequently the secure ruinous tribal wars, while the St Paul's, the Jank, the St. John's, and the SImoe Rivers within Liberian jurisdiction and settled by Colonists are entirely free from such disturbances. It is in the Northwestern and South eastern frontiers of the Republic and in localities within our boundaries distant from the civilized settlements where periodical wars now occur, and where trade is interrupted.

The long pending question relating to the Northwestern boun- dary of the Republic is a source of continual annoyance and imitation; and the arrangement of it appears to be beyond the scope of ordinary diplomacy. The country must be settled by civilized immigrants

It is in view of these facts that the President directs me to ask the assistance of your govenrment to send us a few of the thousand of civilized Christian negroes in your country, who are anxious to cast in their lot with Liberia, but who lack the means of transportation and of u start on their arrival in the land of their fathers.

Large numbers of people in the Southern section of your country of good industrious habits, who would be hardly missed from the six millions of colored people, have been for years making application to the government of the United States for aid to emigrate to the land of their fathers.
These people who would not be missed among you would create anation on this side of the water.

Liberia is theoffspring of Ameircan benevolence and this little Republic in Western Africa has excited an influence upon the adjacent tribes almost without a parallel in the history of Colonies. A few thousand immigrants from the United States have drawn under their influence from the stagnant and barren healthemism of eyes over a million of people, and without face a money have assimi- lated them by industrial, social and religious influence and made them a part of a christian Republic based upon the traditions of the United States.

The Republic of Liberia in these features of freedom and equal of universal education, withotu distinction of classes which so force ably impresss the aboriginal mind, is an illustration of the kind and practice of American institutions. Half of the public domain of Liberia is held in trust for the settlement of the black people of the United States. Every black man in America has a claim to a homestead in Liberia and the government is bound by law to grant ten acres of land to every adult, and twenty-fice acres to every family who come to this country from the United States.
Our selections then to the American government are peculiar and are claim to sympathy and assistance from the United States is almost that of an American Colony.

The President also desires me to say that it would be of in- calculable advantage if one of the United States could be detailed from the Mediterranean squadron since a year between the months of December and March to cruise on the Liberian Coast. This would reatly assist us in maintain ing the prestige of the Republic among the Aborigines at distant point from the settlement along the Coast and in infusing new energy into the movement of our reviewed affairs. The President hope therefore that it will be within the competence and ability of the United States government to come to the help of Liberia in the present emergency

I am further interested to say that for these advantages which we ask of the United States, the government of Liberia will be pre- pared under a special treaty to concede certain privileges to American citizens doing business in Liberia, not granted to other foreigners- privilege which if American capitalists would avail themselves of them, would give them the virtual control of u large portion of the trade of Coastal African and American products and shipping would infer advantages which European traders have many years sought in vain at the hands of the government of Liberia. The whole country lies before the American traders and agriculturists through Liberia the country to the penetration and commercial possession of which French inspiration and energies are now directed.

Should your government take into favorable consider- ation the requests andpropostitions made in this communication and should desire it, the President will appoint one or two special commissioners to visit Washington to treat with the government of the United States in relation to these im- portant matters. Availing myself of this opportunity to assure you of
my very high consideration and esteem. I have the honor to be Sir your most obedient servant. G.W. Gibson
